Proposing as part of 0.9.3 for now as not to block 0.9.2
updated the doc. also changed default pendingTasksRunnerNumThreads = 1 ... we will internally keep it 3 and continue to monitor if any issues are faced.

Priority locking feature is configurable now, by default it is off and can be enabled by setting the runtime property `druid.indexer.taskLockboxVersion` to `v2`. 
- `TaskLockbox` in an interface and there are two implementations - `TaskLockboxV1` which is same as the previous `TaskLockbox` and`TaskLockboxV2` does priority based locking. One of them is injected at runtime in `CliOverlord` and `CliPeon` depending on `druid.indexer.taskLockboxVersion`
- `TaskLockbox` has new method `boolean setTaskLockCriticalState(Task task, Interval interval, TaskLockCriticalState taskLockCriticalState)` meant for upgrading locks in case priority based locking is used. `TaskLockboxV1` always returns `true` for this method.
- `TaskLock` has two new fields `priority` and `upgraded`. In case of `TaskLockboxV1` the corresponding values are always `0` and `true`. For `TaskLockboxV2` it is depended on the task. 
- Each task calls `setTaskLockCriticalState` before publishing segments. However, in case of `TaskLockboxV1` the method always returns `true` and extra overhead is just an HTTP call to overlord. In case of `TaskLockboxV2` it does the actual work of setting TaskLock state.
- `Task` interface has `int getLockPriority()` method which I guess is OK

@rajk-tetration, interesting, I wonder if you need to choose "Druid code style" in your IntelliJ code style settings? Anyway the formatting does look better now.

👍  from me after travis + CLA are sorted.

The error in nested groupBy test is caused by outer query expecting data source to have long value for the metric column created by inner query's longFirst aggregator, but instead got the intermediate value type which is pair[time, value] since inner query result isn't finalized. I feel like inner query's result should be finalized by my understanding on how query as datasource should work, but doing so would break aggregators in outer query that depend on intermediate value such as HyperUnique. The fix I made parsed pair[time, long/double] as long/double for long and double selector in mapBasedRow.
some minor comments, :+1: after those

Hmm, finalizing inner queries makes sense to me…

Is there any reason why they aren't? does anyone know?

@pjain1 It's not guaranteed that all the shards are above the optimal size within 1 iteration. They eventually will after multiple iterations. So it shouldn't require guessing `targetPartitionSize`.

@fjy I will be working on resolving merge conflicts soon.

@drcrallen I did some tests and found it's barely meet the situation (swap and fold). The numbers are mostly identical. If we do some parallel folding it would be a little helpful but currently it seemed not useful. Can we close this?
@julien-lecomte It is work in progress - https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3217
@nishantmonu51 don't forget to tag PRs
Note this will probably still show up in the middle manager launch command logging.
@navis I would rather not add complexity unless it has specific results. The results don't have to be much (5% improvement is totally worth it), but they should be measurable.

Hi Himanshu,

I am not able to get the avro stream to work with the new jar. I have
packaged your changes which produced
"druid-avro-extensions-0.9.2-SNAPSHOT.jar".
I moved the original jar into a subdirectory so that there are no conflicts
and copied the snapshot jar in current directory (imply-1.3.0/dist/druid/
extensions/druid-avro-extensions). Also changed imply-1.3.0/conf-
quickstart/druid/_common/common.runtime.properties to include avro library:

druid.extensions.loadList=["druid-avro-extensions", "druid-histogram",
"druid-datasketches", "druid-kafka-indexing-service"]

I've modified kafka.json in imply-1.3.0/conf-quickstart/tranquility to the
one attached.

Upon starting imply:
bin/supervise -c conf/supervise/quickstart.conf

I do not see any topics being picked in the tranquility logs
[imply-1.3.0/var/sv/tranquility-kafka.log]:
2016-08-08 17:27:56,913 [main] INFO  k.c.ZookeeperConsumerConnector -
[cust1-tranquility_skoppar-mac15.com-1470677276325-37ef097f], Creating
topic event watcher for topics ((?!))

[cust1-tranquility_skoppar-mac15.com-1470677276325-37ef097f], Topics to
consume = List()

Doesn't it mean that no topics have been registered?

Only relevant entries in the log are:
2016-08-08 17:27:56,151 [main] INFO  c.m.t.kafka.writer.WriterController -
Ready: [topicPattern] -> dataSource mappings:
2016-08-08 17:27:56,152 [main] INFO  c.m.t.kafka.writer.WriterController -
  [(?!)] -> AvroSource (priority: 1)

I am new to Druid, so please pardon my ignorance. Is the
publicAvrokafka.json file right? At this point I havent added any business
functionality. The derived fields are coming from an ETL process outside of
Druid. I just want to be able to ingest avro data through kafka and that
doesnt seem to work. To be sure its not a kafka issue, I have tried using
kafka-console-consumer and I can receive events there.

regards
Sunita

I just added docs in querying.md clarifying how exceptions should work now. The behavior is backwards-compatible from the broker standpoint – it only used to return the `"error"` field.

@skoppar i haven't really used kafka with tranquility and information provided does not look like avro parsing related failures.
i don't see any kafka topic etc input information in your spec , not sure how you provide it to tranquility... @gianm can you spot something?

Some examples of errors from the broker, before and after.

Query timeout,
- before: `{"error":"Query timeout"}`
- after: `{"error":"Query timeout","errorMessage":"Timeout waiting for task.","errorClass":"java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException","host":"druid1.example.com:8083"}`

groupBy maxResults exceeded,
- before: `{"error":"Unknown exception"}`
- after: `{"error":"Unknown exception","errorMessage":"Maximum number of rows [500000] reached","errorClass":"com.metamx.common.ISE","host":"druid1.example.com:8083"}`

Thanks for quick response Himanshu.
From what I understand,
"properties": {
  "topicPattern": "raw-cust1"
}

Provides the topic which is per datasource level and below properties provide overall cluster connection. Adding group_id to data source specs might be more advisable, but I haven't tried that yet. I am using all default ports.

"kafka.group.id":"cust1-tranquility",
"zookeeper.connect":"localhost",
"kafka.zookeeper.connect":"localhost"

regards
Sunita

Tried finalizing inner query result, the failing tests are testSubqueryWithHyperUniques for v1 and v2 and testSubqueryWithFirstLast (introduced in this PR) for v1. HyperUniques test failed because the outer query has a HyperUniques aggregator, which requires the pre-finalized value from the inner query result. FirstLast test failed for v1 because v1 builds inner incremental index using combining factory, which assumes intermediate data format.

Hmm, does the "finalize" context param do anything on the inner query? This sounds like a job for finalize. false makes more sense for a default, IMO, but it could be true if it needs to be for compat reasons. Either way, a user should also be able to set it to whatever the non-default value is.

Setting "finalize" appropriately should let the tests pass…

@himanshug since we're updating the API, I wonder if it would make sense to define whether we always return the results before context. This would allow us to stream results back, as well as include some query stats (or other data that we only know after the fact) as part of the context.

Currently "finalize" param for inner query is not used as inner query is run using mergeResults which rewrites query to set "finalize" to false. Finalizing inner query can be added by using mapped sequence on top of the inner query result, maybe in another PR?
@drcrallen thanks, I've re-opened this now, benchmarks have been updated

Another fact is, Zookeeper is able to recognize the consumer group and the
group is visible upon executing zookeeper shell. Also from tranquility
side, zookeeper connection seems to be present. The Kafka broker connection
is what seems to be missing and the topic list is empty as mentioned in the
previous comment. Appreciate any help  @gianm https://github.com/gianm
I also tried with 0.8.2.0-kafka-1.3.0 instead of 0.9.0-kafka-2.0.1

@gianm
I'm more inclined to change IncrementalIndex.getMetricType() to return type from ComplexMetricsSerde as serde is the one responsible for storing data and its type information.

AggregatorFactory.getTypeName() is more of transient information required to read the input data correctly.

what do you think?
@himanshug that sounds good to me.

@himanshug doesnt look like loading the jar is the issue. I could be wrong though. Attaching the indexing-log in imply-1.3.0/var/druid/indexing-logs which shows the druid-avro-extensions-0.9.2-SNAPSHOT.jar being added. Please let me know if I am looking at a wrong place.

@xvrl we discussed the ordering or result and context in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3319#discussion-diff-73443513 
updated the querying documentation with information about new endpoint. I am marking it experimental for now so as to be able to change things in near future if a problem is discovered with the response format proposed here.
@skoppar one of the problems in your json is that "parseSpec" is inside "avroBytesDecoder" while it should be a level up inside "parser" .

oops ! let me relook at the complete json

I think this breaks the impl of `IncrementalIndex.getMetricClass`, which does `ComplexMetrics.getSerdeForType(metricDesc.getType())`. It also breaks IndexMerger, which does something similar. Maybe instead we should modify `IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter.getColumnTypeName` to do a ComplexMetrics.getSerdeForType on the type returned by IncrementalIndex.

Its working now. 2 more changes I had to do was:
1. Specify the format in parseSpec
2. Add the path to druid extensions manually in quickStart.conf 

With that done to the attached conf, I am able to process records with schema inline. However, I do not see the data source in druid console or pivot. I can see metrics-kafka (had run the example), so I was expecting this should show up as well. 

Using topic name - raw-avro for this test. Below is what the tranquility-kafka log shows -  the avro schema and then the below message 
2016-08-09 21:34:23,038 [KafkaConsumer-CommitThread] INFO  c.m.tranquility.kafka.KafkaConsumer - Flushed {raw-avro={**receivedCount=800**, sentCount=0, droppedCount=0, unparseableCount=800}} pending messages in 0ms and committed offsets in 3ms.

hmm, actually maybe it would be "fine" because SketchBuild and SketchMerge act the same way at the points that those methods are called. It still feels more right to defer the translation until the IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter though.
@acslk is a finalization option not needed for making the first/last aggregator work?
Sick, it looks like `IndexMergeBenchmark` accidentally got faster :)

The previous commit added parsing for pair for RowBasedMap which is used by nested groupBy v2, while v1 uses value from IncrementalIndexAdapter which uses aggregator's getLong/getFloat, so both versions works right now without finalization.

Ahh, I hadn't seen that before. hmm, that Pair parsing is kind of weird, though. Namely: What does it mean to "parse" a Pair as a number? Why is the rhs the special one? Why not treat it like a vector and take its magnitude? :)

I recognize the answer is: because that's what makes the first/last aggregators work. But that answer is somewhat unsatisfying – a finalization option would be a lot nicer.

@gianm I haven't benchmarked this change in isolation, but I believe the IndexMerger speedup is from difference in implementation for single value rows here:

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3217/files#diff-4cb77a6cbc8f0534054954700125f6afL252
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3217/files#diff-aa6b53e2cf54c0d4132f9f1ead3f80c2R151

i.e., skipping the unneeded creation of an ArrayBasedIndexedInts and just making the single-value array directly
@rajk-tetration did you get a chance to sign the CLA?
what should the default value for inner query finalize parameter? To keep it the same as before would make the default value false, but it feels more consistent with outer query to have it be true.
hmm, I agree finalize = true makes the most sense, but I think in this case compatibility concerns win. So let's make it false by default.

linking a related issue:
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1885
some minor comments, looks good so far, will review again after query finalization comments from @gianm are resolved

travis why

A hacky workaround is to use `shutdown()` instead of [`shutdownNow()`](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/extensions-core/kafka-extraction-namespace/src/main/java/io/druid/query/lookup/KafkaLookupExtractorFactory.java#L301) on the executor, but that does not account for all the cases. Simply clearing the interrupted status does not work either.

I am currently working on a pull request, but thought to register an issue so that if anyone else faces this problem, they can look up the stack trace.

Thanks for the report @gvsmirnov. Just FYI https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/druid-0.9.1.1/extensions-core/kafka-extraction-namespace/src/main/java/io/druid/query/lookup/KafkaLookupExtractorFactory.java#L231 is supposed to handle this. I'm curious if something is swallowing the InterruptedException without re-setting the thread interrupt status.

An overall better solution would probably be to have the loop exit condition be on a more strict factory lifecycle state.
Do you see the log `Error cancelling future for topic [...]` in the logs?
Also, what point did you try clearing the interrupt status?

Another possible problem is that the stop has two interrupts in it. One at shutdownNow and one at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/druid-0.9.1.1/extensions-core/kafka-extraction-namespace/src/main/java/io/druid/query/lookup/KafkaLookupExtractorFactory.java#L306
